item.title: By: chopstik

item.description: Thanks, traingamer! That's what I was trying to reference... Just couldn't remember it verbatim.

item.title: By: traingamer
item.dc:creator: traingamer
item.content:encoded:
“…disregard the impossible and then, whatever is left, no matter how improbable or unlikely, is the answer.”

That’s Arthur Conan Doyle’s Sherlock Holmes, from “A Scandal in Bohemia”, found in “The Adventures of Sherlock Holmes”. (Although maybe Spock or Data quoted him in an episode.)

See Project Gutenberg: http://www.gutenberg.org/etext/1661

“It is an old maxim of mine that when you have excluded the
impossible, whatever remains, however improbable, must be the
truth.”

item.title: By: LNBruno
item.dc:creator: LNBruno
item.content:encoded:
When you wrote “Somewhat exasperated and not a little sheepishly, I found a co-worker and walked through it on their machine” it reminded me of probably one of the best debugging ideas I ever got: the 15 minute rule.

My mentor once told me: “Spend 15 minutes trying to resolve the issue. If, at the end of that 15 minutes, it’s not fixed, go get someone to look over your shoulder.”

I’ve found in most cases that the other person can almost instantly see the problem, saving me hours of frustration.

For me anyway, that old “can’t see the forest for the trees” mentalitiy is coupled with a bulldog determination to find and fix it myself leading to a lot of frustration. My mentor kept reminding me: “Don’t let your bulldog bark overload your chihuahua programming skills.”

I miss ya, Jim!
